physDesc.p: This letter consists of two typed pages on carbon paper. There is an address header in the upper lefthand corner. The right hand corner has the date line. The second page has a header above the dateline (Mr. Aldington - 2). The year 1920 is written in pencil on the first page in the dateline. The first page has some small tears at the bottom right.

div.p: I went to the “Dial” office the other day when I was in New York and saw the boys. It was rather a curious experience. Schofield Thayer is an aesthete; he goes beyond Ezra and reverts back to Oscar Wilde tradition. His own house is full of red lacquer and Aubrey Beardsley drawings, with an impeccable man-servant to bring in tea, and a liveried chauffeur to take him from his office to the house. This is all silly, and springs from the fact that the boy was brought up in Worcester and has no artistic background at all, wherefore, poor child, he craves for it, and sets out in the wrong way to get it; but I think he is doing all he can to help things along, and were it not for his unbounded admiration for a young fellow named Erstline Cummings who has, I believe, no future, I should have more of an opinion of his taste. He means well, but lacks background, On the other hand, he has associated with him a very interesting fellow named Stewart Donald Mitchell. Thayer has the money and owns the magazine, but I have some hopes of Mitchell if Thayer won't interfere too much. At any rate, they told me they had accepted both of the things you had sent them lately, and Mitchell said they would look up the accounts and see what was owing to you, and pay it. If they do not do it, let me know. This is rather decent of them because it seems that when Martyn Johnson sold the paper to them he left them a sum of money to cover his obligations to contributors, which sum, of course, did not anywhere nearly cover, and I rather think they are not legally obliged to pay his debts, but they say they are quite ready to do so, and I think they will.

Harriet Monroe has sent me a poem of yours called "Eumenides," but I doubt if I can place it as all war literature is at a discount just now. Even the psychology of the aftermath of the war is no longer wanted. I have, however, sent it to the “North American Review”, and I will let you know how things pan out about it.
I have just got back from Texas and have so many things to do that I cannot write much to-day. More anon.
